Post title: Why We Believe AI Can (and Should) Sound More Human
Post SEO title: Why We Believe AI Can (and Should) Sound More Human
Meta description: It‚Äôs a demo of Amazon‚Äôs new Nova Sonic feature ‚Äî engineered to sound and respond like a human in real-time conversation.
Post body:
Welcome to "No Excuses: CX Leadership Chronicles" -  the go-to source for insights, strategies, and best practices in customer experience leadership. At CloudInteract, we believe there‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. This philosophy, championed by our co-founder and CEO Simon Leyland, drives everything we do as we help businesses reimagine their customer interactions.

When we started CloudInteract, we set out to rid the world of rubbish contact centres. That might sound bold ‚Äî but bad service is something none of us should accept anymore.

And we mean it when we say: there‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service.

Today, we‚Äôre more certain than ever that we can significantly improve any contact centre. One of the biggest issues we see time and again? Contact centres overwhelmed with simple, repetitive queries. In fact, agents spend more than 50% of their time answering straightforward, repeatable questions.

It‚Äôs easy to say that these should be handled via websites or text-based chatbots ‚Äî but the reality is, people still like to pick up the phone. Those simple questions get lumped in with the complicated and complex ones, making it harder for customers with real issues to get the help they need.

Our Two-Stage Approach

At CloudInteract, we tackle this in two stages.

Stage One is about getting under the skin of the problem. We give contact centres clear, detailed insight into what‚Äôs really going on ‚Äî not just how long calls take, but what they‚Äôre about. We identify which queries are simple, which are complicated, and which are truly complex. We then make tailored recommendations on how to streamline, automate or enhance those experiences. During this phase, we also collect real-life questions and answers to help pre-populate knowledge bases and AI agents.

Stage Two is where it gets exciting. We start deploying AI agents, using next-gen technology like AWS Nova Sonic and Amazon Connect Unlimited AI to handle those high-volume, simple queries. These agents are always-on, always-available, and can scale fast to meet spikes in demand ‚Äî especially during critical or time-sensitive situations.

For your human agents, we use Amazon Q in Connect to give them the tools they need to quickly find answers to more complex or nuanced problems. This means faster responses, better service, and happier teams.

So, What Does That Actually Sound Like?

Let‚Äôs take a real-world example. One of our pharmacy clients receives a high volume of calls about temperature-sensitive deliveries. These are time-critical and often cause a huge spike in demand.

By placing an AI agent at the start of the call, we can resolve many of these queries immediately ‚Äî while still offering the option to speak to a human. What‚Äôs different here is the experience ‚Äî because thanks to clever engineering, this AI interaction doesn‚Äôt sound robotic. It sounds natural. Human. Helpful.

üéß Listen for yourself.

Here‚Äôs a short, voice-only demo using Amazon Nova Sonic. It‚Äôs a person talking to an AI chatbot ‚Äî but you‚Äôd be forgiven for not knowing which is which. From tone and timing to the flow of the conversation, this is next-level voice tech in action.

üéß Hit play, close your eyes, and see if you can tell where the human ends and the AI begins.

At CloudInteract, we believe there‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service ‚Äî and technology like Nova Sonic helps us reimagine how every conversation can feel more human, more helpful, and more connected.

Why Voice Still Matters

It‚Äôs important we provide consistent, high-quality responses across every channel ‚Äî and that‚Äôs why we favour Amazon Connect. With voice, text, chat, video, and AI agents all integrated into one platform, we can offer seamless, context-aware experiences, however your customers choose to get in touch.

Want to see how this could work in your contact centre?

Let‚Äôs talk. We‚Äôll show you what‚Äôs possible ‚Äî and how your agents, customers, and bottom line will all benefit. {{cta('205068514499')}}

Post title: What Happens When Every Contact Counts
Post SEO title: What Happens When Every Contact Counts
Meta description: Why mindset matters in customer experience - and how data and design unlock better outcomes.
Post body:
Why mindset matters in customer experience - and how data and design unlock better outcomes

Most organisations would say they care about customer experience. But in reality, many still treat contact centre interactions as isolated transactions - a ticket to be resolved, a call to be answered, a query to be closed.

The shift comes when businesses start to see each interaction as more than just a moment in time. When they operate as if every contact counts, everything changes: for customers, for frontline teams, and for the organisation as a whole.

The Cost of Missed Moments

When contact centres are under pressure with high volumes, disconnected systems, and generic scripts, it‚Äôs easy to fall into reactive mode. But every time a customer has to repeat themselves, is transferred between teams, or is given irrelevant advice, value is lost.

Not just in the immediate interaction, but in brand trust, customer retention, and team morale.

  • A misrouted call can delay resolution by minutes - or days.
  • A missed opportunity to personalise the conversation can lead to churn.
  • A lack of context can result in unnecessary follow-ups and cost.

These small moments accumulate - and they compound over time.

Meet ‚ÄúRamesh,‚Äù follow his story, and see how Apollo spotted missed opportunities and recommended smarter CX strategies - all in real-time. üëâ

What it Looks Like When Every Contact Does Count

When businesses shift to a mindset where every interaction matters, we see clear differences:

  • Conversations become connected: Customers are recognised, not restarted. Agents can pick up the thread from previous interactions across voice and digital channels.
  • Agents are empowered: They have the information and tools to resolve issues first time, with confidence and context.
  • Decisions are driven by data: Leaders have real-time insight into what‚Äôs happening across teams, channels, and geographies - enabling faster course correction and continuous improvement.
  • Customers feel seen and heard: Which builds long-term loyalty and brand advocacy.

What Enables This?

Technology plays a critical role - but only when it‚Äôs designed to serve the people using it.

That‚Äôs why we built Apollo. Not just to enhance the technology stack, but to support a more intentional, insight-led approach to customer interactions.

Apollo enables this mindset shift by:

  • Bringing data together in real time: So agents and supervisors have the full picture at the point of contact
  • Supporting personalisation at scale: With relevant customer context surfaced automatically
  • Enabling agility and experimentation: So teams can test, learn, and adapt faster
  • Turning contact data into actionable insight: Not just for CX leaders, but across the business

It‚Äôs not just about doing more. It‚Äôs about doing better - because when every contact counts, better isn‚Äôt optional.

Mindset Before Metrics

Ultimately, acting like every contact counts is a cultural and leadership shift as much as a technical one. It‚Äôs about embedding the belief that every interaction is an opportunity to solve, to connect, to improve.

The right technology supports this belief. It doesn‚Äôt replace the people who deliver the experience; it enables them to do it well, every time.

If you‚Äôre ready to explore what this could look like for your organisation, let‚Äôs start a conversation. We‚Äôll show you how Apollo helps contact centres move from transactional to transformational - one contact at a time.

Post title: Amazon Nova Sonic: The Missing Piece in Natural Voice Automation?
Post SEO title: Amazon Nova Sonic: The Missing Piece in Natural Voice Automation?
Meta description: Voice matters. In a world where every customer interaction counts, how something sounds can change how someone feels.
Post body:
Voice matters. In a world where every customer interaction counts, how something sounds can change how someone feels: about the experience, about the brand, and about whether they come back.

That‚Äôs why Amazon‚Äôs latest innovation, Nova Sonic, is such a big deal.

From Nick Seagrave, CTO and Co-Founder
There‚Äôs a lot of noise out there when it comes to ‚Äúhuman-like AI‚Äù ‚Äî but this one‚Äôs worth paying attention to. Amazon Nova Sonic isn‚Äôt just a shiny new model. It solves a real problem: how to make voice interactions with AI actually feel natural. No lag. No clunky stitching of parts. Just fast, fluid conversations that sound like they should.

This blog breaks down what it is, why it matters, and what we‚Äôre doing with it at CloudInteract.

Check out our short demo video, which showcases the integration of Amazon Nova Sonic with our AI-powered customer experience platform... üëá

So, what is Nova Sonic ‚Äî and why should we care?

Put simply, Nova Sonic is a major step forward in making conversations with AI feel truly human.

Until now, AI-powered voice interactions - think voicebots, contact centre virtual agents, or digital assistants - have felt disjointed. The tech behind the scenes was stitched together like a relay race:

  • One part transcribed your voice.
  • Another tried to work out what you meant.
  • A third generated a reply.
  • Then a final piece turned that into a voice.

It worked, but you could hear the clunkiness. The awkward pauses. The robotic tone. And all of it chipped away at the kind of effortless experience we all strive to deliver.

Nova Sonic changes that. It‚Äôs a single, unified model that understands and responds in real time; just like a human would in conversation.

That means:

  • No more unnatural gaps.
  • More lifelike tone, pace, and inflection.
  • A smoother, faster, more intuitive experience.

It‚Äôs the kind of shift that could redefine what ‚Äúgood‚Äù sounds like in customer experience.

What it means for CloudInteract ‚Äî and our customers

At CloudInteract, we‚Äôre all about reimagining how customers connect with the brands they choose. And voice plays a huge role in that. It‚Äôs the first impression, the tone-setter, the moment that can turn frustration into confidence - or the other way around.

Which is why we‚Äôre already on it.

Our engineering team is actively exploring how Nova Sonic can be integrated into the services we deliver; with the goal of creating more natural, more empathetic, and more impactful voice experiences for our clients.

Think:

  • Virtual agents that feel genuinely conversational (but scale like tech).
  • Customer journeys with less friction and more emotional intelligence.
  • A brand experience that feels human from the very first ‚Äúhello.‚Äù

We believe Nova Sonic may well be the final piece of the puzzle when it comes to building truly natural voice automation. And we‚Äôre committed to unlocking its potential ‚Äî not just because it‚Äôs exciting technology, but because it helps us do what we‚Äôre here to do: deliver meaningful, better experiences at scale.

Stay tuned - we‚Äôre just getting started.

Post title: Building Momentum: The Five Pillars of Sustained Adoption Success
Post SEO title: Building Momentum: The Five Pillars of Sustained Adoption Success
Meta description: Rolling out new technology is one thing. Making it stick - and delivering real, lasting value - is another. For CX leaders and change professionals, the true challenge lies not just in launching change but in embedding it. That‚Äôs where Adoption Momentum comes in.
Post body:
Rolling out new technology is one thing. Making it stick - and delivering real, lasting value - is another. For CX leaders and change professionals, the true challenge lies not just in launching change but in embedding it. That‚Äôs where Adoption Momentum comes in.

This blog explores the five essential pillars that can help you create lasting adoption success - by focusing on the people behind the process, enabling progress, and driving cultural change. Whether you're rolling out a new contact centre platform, AI capability, or internal tools, these pillars will help you move beyond go-live to real, embedded transformation.

1.     Leadership & Vision: Set the Tone from the Top

Change needs a champion - and that starts with leadership. When leaders visibly back a transformation, model the new behaviours, and consistently communicate the 'why,' teams are more likely to follow.

But it‚Äôs more than just cheerleading. It‚Äôs about linking the change to meaningful business goals and customer outcomes. When people understand how their work contributes to something bigger - and see that their leaders are invested - they‚Äôre far more likely to embrace change and carry it forward.

Top Tip: Use leadership comms not just to inform, but to inspire. And make sure change is owned across the leadership team‚Äînot just by IT or project leads.

2.     Engaging & Equipping Users: Empower People, Reduce Resistance

You can‚Äôt achieve sustained adoption without putting users at the heart of your strategy. Training should be more than a tick-box exercise. It should be relevant, role-specific, and continuous.

People need to feel confident - not just on Day 1, but as new features, tools, or workflows roll out. Peer learning, communities of practice, and on-demand resources go a long way in supporting users when they need help most.

Top Tip: Empower early adopters to become advocates. Their real-world insights and support can reduce resistance and build peer trust.

3.     Quick Wins & Measurable Impact: Show Progress Early

Momentum builds when people see progress. Early success stories - especially when linked to real-world benefits like saved time, improved customer feedback, or better performance - help motivate teams and prove that the change is worth it.

Tracking the right metrics matters too. It‚Äôs not just about usage - it‚Äôs about value. What behaviours are changing? What outcomes are improving?

Top Tip: Capture, share, and celebrate wins loudly and often. Storytelling fuels belief - and belief drives adoption.

4.     Feedback Loops & Continuous Improvement: Listen, Adapt, Evolve

Sustainable change doesn‚Äôt happen in a straight line. It evolves - and to evolve effectively, you need to listen.

Whether through structured surveys, drop-in sessions, or usage analytics, make it easy for users to share feedback - and act on it. This not only improves the experience but shows teams that their voices matter.

Top Tip: Keep a visible backlog of user suggestions and updates. When people see their input reflected in the product or process, engagement grows.

5.     Long-Term Reinforcement & Culture Shift: From Adoption to Evolution

Once the dust settles, the real work begins. Embedding new ways of working into everyday routines is critical for long-term success.

This means aligning new tools with daily workflows, rewarding champions, and continuing to communicate progress and evolution. The end goal? A culture that sees change as a constant - and adapts accordingly.

Top Tip: Make continuous improvement part of your operating rhythm. Create space for reflection, review, and re-education to keep your adoption momentum alive.

Ready to Build Adoption Momentum?

Adoption isn‚Äôt a one-time event - it‚Äôs a journey. These five pillars are designed to help you sustain momentum long after go-live, creating a culture of continuous improvement and positive change.

If you‚Äôre ready to reimagine how change works in your organisation, we‚Äôre here to help.

Post title: What's New in Amazon Connect - March 2025
Post SEO title: What's New in Amazon Connect - March 2025
Meta description: From first-party AI across every channel to more intuitive tools for supervisors and agents alike, Amazon Connect continues to evolve at pace.
Post body:
Amazon Connect: What's New - March 2025

New features, powerful improvements ‚Äì see what‚Äôs landed in Amazon Connect this March.

From first-party AI across every channel to more intuitive tools for supervisors and agents alike, Amazon Connect continues to evolve at pace. March 2025 brings a fresh set of features designed to simplify operations, unlock intelligence, and boost performance across your contact centre. Here‚Äôs a roundup of what‚Äôs new, what‚Äôs useful, and what to look out for next.


Hot off the press from our resident Contact Centre Consultant and AWS Solution Architect, Alex Baker. Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new this month:

{{cta('221218590962','justifycenter')}}

 

The Next Generation of Amazon Connect

Announced at Enterprise Connect 2025, the latest version of Amazon Connect is being dubbed the "next generation" ‚Äì and for good reason. It brings together AI-powered capabilities across all channels, combined with a simplified all-you-can-eat pricing model.

Key highlights:

  • One pricing model for voice, chat, AI features (like Contact Lens), scheduling, and Amazon Q in Connect

  • Communication costs (e.g. telephony) still charged separately

  • Greater ease of adoption for AI tools across operations

üëâ Read more on the AWS blog

New Analytics Features: Amazon Connect Analytics Data Lake

A major step forward for reporting and insights, the Amazon Connect Data Lake provides a unified source for contact records, agent metrics, Contact Lens data, and more. New table updates make it easier to deep-dive into performance across:

  • Lex bots

  • Outbound campaigns

  • Evaluation forms
    API updates also support idempotency for more reliable data integration.

üëâ Explore the release notes

Agent Shift Bidding and Exchange

Now in FCS, agents can initiate shift trades with each other‚Äîwithout needing to take time off.
Managers can choose which trades are auto-approved and which need manual sign-off, depending on customer segment or task criticality. A great step toward flexibility without losing control.

üé• Watch the YouTube demo

Dynamic Evaluation Forms

Say goodbye to form overload. Evaluation forms can now show or hide follow-up questions based on earlier responses. For example, if a customer made a purchase on a call, the form can automatically surface a question about sales disclosures.

üëâ Read more in the Admin Guide

Proficiency-Based Routing ‚Äì More Updates

Previously, routing criteria could be updated only three times while a contact waited in queue. That limit‚Äôs gone. You can now update routing criteria as many times as needed‚Äîalthough only the last three are stored for metrics reporting.

Configure Amazon Q in Connect from the Admin Console

Admins can now set up AI agents, custom prompts, and content guardrails directly within the Amazon Connect admin site. This means less time jumping between tools, and more time getting the AI experience right.

üîß Try the updated Amazon Q workshop

Native Voicemail with IVR Recording

There‚Äôs now an AWS-provided GitHub solution for capturing voicemail in the IVR leg‚Äîsomething that previously required Kinesis Video Streams. It creates a task and routes it to an agent with the voicemail recording attached. Fewer moving parts = easier implementation.

üîó Check out the GitHub project

Final Thoughts

From real-time AI agents to smarter analytics and pricing flexibility, the March 2025 updates mark a significant step in the evolution of Amazon Connect. These features bring new levels of intelligence, automation, and configurability to contact centres looking to transform customer experience.

Need help assessing what these changes mean for your environment?
üëâ Book a 30-minute envisioning session with our Amazon Connect experts and let‚Äôs reimagine what‚Äôs possible.

Excited to learn more? Download our What‚Äôs New in Amazon Connect overview.

{{cta('221218590951','justifycenter')}}

Stay tuned for more updates as we continue to innovate and support your customer experience journey with Amazon Connect!

Post title: The Customer Experience Problem We Can No Longer Ignore
Post SEO title: The Customer Experience Problem We Can No Longer Ignore
Meta description: The future of customer experience is not just about doing more with less - it is about doing better with what we have.
Post body:
Welcome to "No Excuses: CX Leadership Chronicles" -  the go-to source for insights, strategies, and best practices in customer experience leadership. At CloudInteract, we believe there‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. This philosophy, championed by our co-founder and CEO Simon Leyland, drives everything we do as we help businesses reimagine their customer interactions.

Customer experience has reached a tipping point. For years, businesses have optimised contact centres for efficiency, reducing costs, and increasing agent productivity - often at the expense of the customer. The result? Widespread frustration, rising attrition rates, and a contact centre model that is no longer fit for purpose.

Customers expect seamless, intelligent, and personalised interactions. They don‚Äôt have patience for long wait times, disjointed service, or robotic, scripted responses. Yet, many organisations remain locked into legacy thinking, measuring success with outdated KPIs that reward speed over substance and cost-cutting over customer value.

The truth is, we cannot keep applying efficiency-driven metrics to a system that is no longer efficient. It is time to fundamentally rethink the way we design, measure, and deliver customer experience.

Why Traditional Contact Centre Models Are Failing

The problem isn‚Äôt that contact centres aren‚Äôt trying to improve; it‚Äôs that they are solving the wrong things.

The industry has long prioritised efficiency over effectiveness - focusing on metrics such as average handle time, speed to answer, and abandonment rates. But these do not tell us whether customers actually got what they needed. The obsession with reducing costs has led to a system where customer service is often treated as a necessary expense rather than a strategic advantage.

Meanwhile, advances in AI and automation have created an expectation gap. Customers know that businesses have access to better tools, faster systems, and richer data than ever before. They don‚Äôt understand why they still have to repeat their issue three times, be transferred between departments, or explain their history every time they contact support. 

üëâ Head over to our Apollo Content Hub to read more about our advances in AI Data Intelligence 

The frustration isn‚Äôt just on the customer side. Agents are equally constrained by outdated processes. Many spend their time navigating fragmented systems, manually inputting data, or handling repetitive queries that could - and should - be automated. This is leading to burnout, disengagement, and high attrition rates.

This is not just a technology problem; it is a fundamental design flaw in how businesses think about customer experience.

Pearson, a global education provider was struggling with an outdated contact centre that couldn‚Äôt scale, weighed down by high costs, rigid licensing, and limited AI integration. Partnering with CloudInteract, they moved to Amazon Connect, automating routine enquiries, optimising agent efficiency, and reducing operational costs - unlocking $7 million in projected savings over three years. This wasn‚Äôt about replacing people with AI but giving them the right tools to deliver better, faster, and more effective support.

{{cta('194158518459','justifycenter')}}

Beyond Automation: Rethinking the Role of AI in CX

The promise of AI in customer experience is often misunderstood. AI is not about replacing human service - it is about enhancing it. Yet, too many organisations either resist automation entirely or rush to implement it without a clear strategy.

The result is a disjointed experience: customers encountering unintelligent chatbots, frustrating self-service options, or AI-driven systems that lack real-world application.

The businesses that will thrive in the next evolution of CX are those that recognise:

  • AI should eliminate friction, not create it. It should remove the barriers that frustrate customers - such as lengthy verification processes, repetitive authentication, and unnecessary call transfers.
  • AI should empower agents, not replace them. The role of automation is to handle the routine so that human expertise can be focused where it is most valuable - on complex, high-value interactions.
  • AI should deliver real intelligence, not just automation. This means using AI to extract meaningful insights from customer interactions, identify patterns, and anticipate issues before they escalate.

Simply automating what is broken will not fix the problem. AI must be intelligently applied to create a contact centre that is not just more efficient, but fundamentally better.

A leading digital healthcare provider was struggling with high call volumes, manual workflows, and limited visibility into customer interactions. Despite using Amazon Connect, they weren‚Äôt tapping into AI‚Äôs full potential. Partnering with CloudInteract, they deployed Apollo to enable real-time transcription and sentiment analysis, automate quality management, and streamline workforce scheduling. The result? A shift from a reactive, labour-intensive contact centre to an intelligent, insight-driven operation - boosting efficiency, improving agent performance, and enhancing service quality.

{{cta('194157723885','justifycenter')}}

Fixing the Visibility Problem in CX

One of the biggest reasons businesses struggle to improve customer experience is a lack of visibility.

  • Do you know why customers are really contacting your business?
  • Can you see patterns in your contact centre data that reveal emerging customer needs?
  • Do your agents have real-time access to the insights they need to resolve issues efficiently?

Too often, the answer is no.

Most contact centres operate in silos, with data trapped across multiple systems. This lack of integration means that customer history is incomplete, agent workflows are inefficient, and leadership teams make decisions based on lagging indicators rather than real-time intelligence.

Without the ability to analyse and act on real customer interactions, businesses remain reactive - addressing issues only after they become problems.

Solving this requires more than just better reporting tools. It requires a fundamental shift in how businesses collect, analyse, and apply customer data. The contact centre must move from being a cost centre focused on resolution to an intelligence centre that drives business-wide customer strategy.

Swoop, an adventure travel company needed to grow without losing the personal touch that set them apart. With CloudInteract and Amazon Connect, they gained real-time visibility into customer interactions, used AI-driven insights to refine service delivery, and built a foundation for seamless omnichannel engagement. For them, growth wasn‚Äôt just about automation - it was about making smarter, data-driven decisions to enhance every customer experience.

{{cta('194157723871','justifycenter')}}

Measuring What Matters: The Case for New CX Metrics

If customer experience is to improve, we need to start measuring the right things.

For too long, the industry has relied on KPIs that reward speed and efficiency, often at the expense of customer satisfaction. A three-minute call that leaves a customer frustrated is not better than a twenty-minute call that resolves their issue and strengthens their loyalty.

The most forward-thinking organisations are shifting towards experience-driven metrics, such as:

  • Customer Effort Score (CES): How easy was it for the customer to get help?
  • First Contact Resolution (FCR): Was the issue resolved in a single interaction?
  • Agent Enablement Index: Do employees have the right tools and insights to serve customers effectively?

These are the metrics that truly reflect whether a contact center is delivering meaningful customer experiences.

By realigning KPIs to focus on outcomes rather than outputs, businesses can ensure they are driving the behaviours that lead to better service, stronger relationships, and long-term loyalty.

What‚Äôs Next: The Future of CX

The future of customer experience is not just about doing more with less - it is about doing better with what we have.

The businesses that will lead in CX over the next decade will be those that:

  • Recognise AI as an enabler, not a disruptor. AI should enhance human interactions, not replace them.
  • Prioritise insight over efficiency. Contact centres should be a source of intelligence that informs business strategy, not just a function that manages transactions.
  • Redefine success beyond cost-cutting. Organisations must measure CX based on the value delivered to the customer, not just the cost saved by the business.

This is not just a technology shift - it is a mindset shift. And those who embrace it will create customer experiences that are not only more efficient but truly transformative.

The real question is: Are we ready to lead that change?

At CloudInteract, we help companies reimagine customer service by implementing smart, scalable, and customer-centric contact solutions. If you‚Äôre struggling with legacy barriers, inefficient service channels, or simply don‚Äôt know where to start, let‚Äôs talk. There‚Äôs a better way - and we can help you get there. 

Book a 30-minute strategy session to see how you can transform your customer contact strategy and stop serving your customers to competitors. 

{{cta('205068514499','justifycenter')}}

There‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. And at CloudInteract, we‚Äôre proving there‚Äôs no excuse for standing still, either.

Post title: Lessons from Leading Change in Complex Organisations
Post SEO title: Lessons from Leading Change in Complex Organisations
Meta description: Change is the only constant, and this goes for your plans too. It‚Äôs essential to have a solid strategy and a well-crafted plan but be ready to adjust and adapt on the fly.
Post body:
Welcome to our new series: Momentum: The Change Journey! 

Change isn‚Äôt just about new technology or processes - it‚Äôs about people. Momentum: The Change Journey is a series dedicated to unlocking the power of effective change management, helping organisations move from resistance to readiness, and ensuring that transformation sticks. Through expert insights, practical strategies, and real-world stories, we‚Äôll explore how to build adoption momentum and create lasting impact.

I‚Äôve got to be honest, sometimes leading change can feel like herding cats through a maze in a thunderstorm. Because business never stays the same, even similar initiatives can play out in very different ways. So, I want to talk about some real-world lessons that I‚Äôve picked up along the way.

Eliza Taylor | Change Director

The Rollercoaster of Change

Change is the only constant, and this goes for your plans too. It‚Äôs essential to have a solid strategy and a well-crafted plan but be ready to adjust and adapt on the fly.

It‚Äôs these times of crisis that really shape how people perceive your change. I‚Äôve had projects where a series of just-managed-disasters were spoken of positively in years to come. I gained more grey hairs, and I felt like we‚Äôd barely made it by the skin of our teeth ‚Äì but I got comments afterwards about how it was one of the best managed changes the employees had ever been through ‚Äì that they couldn‚Äôt believe the amount of time and support we had for them, even though it wasn‚Äôt a perfectly smooth ride.

It‚Äôs really tempting to go for the short-term fix, or the knee-jerk reaction in times of crisis. But if you don‚Äôt force yourself to get some perspective and think strategically, you‚Äôll create more problems down the line. So, if you‚Äôre like me, and react best when you feel in control, make sure that you have backup plans for emergencies. Figure out the most important parts of your change plan and decide in advance what options you have in the case of any‚Ä¶hiccups.

Miscommunication

Sometimes it‚Äôs easy to overlook the team delivering the change. We get so involved in mapping, assessing and communicating with the impacted employees that we forget about our own people.

Project teams are usually a collaborative force, drawn together from a couple of different parts of the business, perhaps with loaned, part-time or contractual resources thrown in. Do you have robust systems of communication and collaboration in place for your internal team? Does everyone know who is doing what, for who, and when?

If you can engineer a new way of working for others, you can put in place a few simple controls and checkpoints to keep your own crew up-to-date, aligned and motivated.

Fail to do this and you‚Äôll find challenges harder to deal with and will probably create a few unnecessary ones of your own that could have been avoided. You wouldn‚Äôt believe the number of mishaps that could be avoided if the project team were better aligned.

People aren‚Äôt perfect

No one has an unlimited budget (but if you know someone who does, introduce me - I‚Äôve got some great ideas for spending it)!

In reality, even the best-planned changes won't be perfect. This often makes people feel like imposters because there's a big gap between what theories, research, and blogs say and what's actually doable. This can make us feel pretty inadequate.

But don‚Äôt worry; everyone works with limited teams, budgets, and resources. The trick is in how you use them. That‚Äôs where one of the best tools in your arsenal should come into play ‚Äì the change impact assessment. Use the impact assessment to figure out where your most critical factors are ‚Äì the biggest risks, potential impacts, and what could derail your project.

Here are a few simple questions ‚Äì if you can‚Äôt answer them, then you aren‚Äôt ready for your change:

  • Who will be impacted by the change ‚Äì exactly how many people, in how many teams, and in which parts of the business (and which locations)?
  • How much do they know about the change? Who are they mostly likely to listen/pay attention to at work ‚Äì what are those people telling them about the change?
  • Out of all the roles affected by the change ‚Äì which one is most impacted (i.e. biggest difference to their day to day) and which one is most important to the business (i.e. biggest business risk)? Hint: these may not be the same!

It may seem like a lot of detail but if your project doesn‚Äôt have this info you‚Äôre flying blind, making it way harder to manage resources efficiently and avoid last-minute crises. This can hurt the overall success of what could be an amazing change initiative.

Power players

Outside of your project team, there are some key people who you need to focus on because they can make your change infinitely easier (or harder).

The Top Dog

  • First up is an engaged Executive. Find the most senior person who cares about what you‚Äôre doing ‚Äì this may be the project Executive Sponsor, or their boss, or the head honcho of the whole place. This is your ‚Äòbig gun‚Äô ‚Äì don‚Äôt expect them to be in the details, but they‚Äôll launch you off the starting line and can perk up an initiative that‚Äôs flagging in the middle.
  • Can you deliver change without this Executive? Yes. But it‚Äôll feel like you‚Äôre doing it with lead balloons tied to your feet.

Business Collaborators

  • Next, we have your stakeholders. These are key people across the impacted business who may not have the final say but are going to have a strong opinion and probably won‚Äôt be shy about giving it. They have seniority and expertise in the areas you‚Äôre affecting, and you need to work closely with them to get the green light.
  • In my personal opinion, ‚Äúmanaging stakeholders‚Äù sets things off on the wrong foot. ‚ÄúEngaging stakeholders‚Äù would be a better start ‚Äì if these experts and key representatives aren‚Äôt convinced about your change, then you‚Äôre about to go off the rails. When they believe in what you‚Äôre doing, stakeholders can be powerful (and essential) amplifiers.

Influencers

  • Finally, let's talk about team dynamics. Think back to every team you‚Äôve ever worked with, and you‚Äôll soon find a few key characters reappearing ‚Äì the person who was always keen on new things, and the deeply entrenched skeptic. Now think about how often their strong opinions held sway with the rest of the team who were mostly on the fence.
  • Focus your efforts tapping into the enthusiasts. Boost their voices ‚Äì give them the tools, information and support they need to be advocates for your change, and you‚Äôll positively influence the rest of the team (although the skeptic might never get onboard). These are your early adopters, your change agents, your champions.

While you might pull off successful change without these groups, having them involved makes everything easier, smoother, and way more effective.

Where‚Äôs the Kool-Aid?

As change leaders, it‚Äôs critical to believe in the change we're advocating ‚Äì we must ‚Äúdrink our own Kool-Aid‚Äù. If we don't, how can we expect others to? Share your vision, your passion, and your belief in the change. And if you don‚Äôt believe in the change, then work out why and fix it. Positivity is infectious so celebrate publicly and often, even if the wins seem small.

Leading change in complex organizations isn‚Äôt for the faint-hearted. It requires resilience, adaptability, and a whole lot of heart. Remember, it‚Äôs not about having the perfect resources or time. It‚Äôs about making the most of what you have, prioritising effectively, and celebrating every step forward.

So, to all the change leaders out there, keep pushing, keep believing, and keep celebrating those small victories. You‚Äôve got this!

If you're interested in taking advantage of our free 30-minute strategy session, or you want to take me up on the coffee offer, book your session below, or you can use good old-fashioned email to drop me a note: eliza.taylor@cloudinteract.io

Post title: The High Cost of Avoiding your Customers
Post SEO title: The High Cost of Avoiding your Customers
Meta description: We‚Äôve all been there. Desperately needing support, only to be met with friction at every turn. No digital channels. No flexibility. No empathy. Just a process built for operational efficiency at the expense of customer experience. And we wonder why customers leave.¬†
Post body:
Welcome to "No Excuses: CX Leadership Chronicles" -  the go-to source for insights, strategies, and best practices in customer experience leadership. At CloudInteract, we believe there‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. This philosophy, championed by our co-founder and CEO Simon Leyland, drives everything we do as we help businesses reimagine their customer interactions.

There‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. Yet, here we are ‚Äì again - talking about another well-established financial services provider making it near-impossible for customers to get the help they need. 

It‚Äôs 2025, and people still can‚Äôt send a message to their bank when a transaction goes missing. Instead, they‚Äôre forced to call at the hours that suit the bank, not the customer. No digital contact options, no real-time self-service, just a static FAQ page that, unsurprisingly, doesn‚Äôt have the answers needed. And it‚Äôs not just one company - this is happening across industries. 

We‚Äôve all been there. Desperately needing support, only to be met with friction at every turn. No digital channels. No flexibility. No empathy. Just a process built for operational efficiency at the expense of customer experience. And we wonder why customers leave. 

Why Are We Still Here? 

I understand the internal justifications. Legacy systems. Compliance restrictions. Fear of change. But none of these should stand in the way of offering a simple, effective way for customers to contact you. At the very least, let them send a message. 

Here‚Äôs a reality check: the companies making it hard for customers to get in touch aren‚Äôt saving money - they‚Äôre handing customers over to competitors. Every interaction is an opportunity. Every touchpoint builds trust (or erodes it). The cost of acquiring a new customer is significantly higher than keeping an existing one, yet many brands invest heavily in marketing only to let customers slip away when they actually need support. 

The financial sector is particularly guilty of this. Some banks still refuse to offer even the most basic digital service options. Others cut voice support down to the bare minimum, frustrating customers to the point where they‚Äôll do anything to avoid calling. 

And then there are the horror stories. One major bank cancelled all of a customers‚Äô cards on Christmas Eve due to ‚Äòsuspicious activity‚Äô - but their security team was off until December 27. No override. No escalation. Just a system that said no. Lucky for them, they had another card. Not everyone does. 

The Price of Avoidance 

Companies that restrict service channels aren‚Äôt just making life harder for customers - they‚Äôre actively damaging their brand. 

Let‚Äôs break it down: 

  • Lost Revenue: If customers can‚Äôt reach you, they‚Äôll go elsewhere. That ‚Äòcost per contact‚Äô you‚Äôre trying to reduce? It‚Äôs nothing compared to the cost of losing a customer for life. 
  • Brand Erosion: Today‚Äôs customers don‚Äôt just tolerate bad service. They call it out. Publicly. On social media, review sites, and industry forums. And once your reputation takes a hit, it‚Äôs hard to recover. 
  • Missed Opportunities: Every customer interaction is a chance to strengthen loyalty, drive cross-sell and upsell, or gain invaluable feedback. By cutting off easy access, you‚Äôre not just avoiding costs - you‚Äôre avoiding growth. 

A Better Way Forward 

Fixing this isn‚Äôt about adding more channels for the sake of it. It‚Äôs about strategically designing customer contact to be effortless, intelligent, and valuable for both the customer and the business. 

Here‚Äôs what good looks like: 

  1. Digital-first, but not digital-only ‚Äì Customers expect seamless options: self-service, messaging, chat, and voice when they need it. 
  2. Smart, structured interactions ‚Äì Instead of blocking contact, create structured digital forms to capture key details and streamline responses. 
  3. Personalisation at scale ‚Äì AI-powered systems can help businesses prioritise high-value or urgent cases while automating routine inquiries. 
  1. Always-on, customer-first mindset ‚Äì Service shouldn‚Äôt stop at 5 PM. Whether through automation, async messaging, or intelligent routing, businesses need to be accessible when customers need them. 

The Companies That Will Win 

The businesses that survive and thrive in the coming years will be the ones that put customers first, not themselves. Those who still see customer service as a cost centre instead of a value driver will be left behind. Natural selection will take care of the rest. 

At CloudInteract, we help companies reimagine customer service by implementing smart, scalable, and customer-centric contact solutions. If you‚Äôre struggling with legacy barriers, inefficient service channels, or simply don‚Äôt know where to start, let‚Äôs talk. There‚Äôs a better way - and we can help you get there. 

Book a 30-minute strategy session to see how you can transform your customer contact strategy and stop serving your customers to competitors. 

{{cta('205068514499','justifycenter')}}


There‚Äôs no excuse for bad customer service. And at CloudInteract, we‚Äôre proving there‚Äôs no excuse for standing still, either.

Post title: Technical Project Manager
Post SEO title: Technical Project Manager
Meta description: The Technical Project Manager will be responsible for leading teams to deliver projects that span across one or more business units, managing resources, schedules, financials, and adhering to quality control guidelines throughout the full systems development life cycle.
Post body:
Job Title: Technical Project Manager

Location: Fully Remote (based in either the US or UK)

Reports To: Delivery Lead

How to Apply: To apply for this role, please click the "submit" button and attach your CV to the email. Please clearly indicate in the subject line which role you are applying for. You may attach an optional covering letter or any further supporting documents. 

{{cta('215706227956','justifycenter')}}

Job Summary: 

The Technical Project Manager will be responsible for leading teams to deliver projects that span across one or more business unit, managing resources, schedules, financials, and adhering to quality control guidelines throughout the full systems development life cycle. This includes managing issues, risks, and project change requests to ensure successful and on-time, within budget, project delivery. The ideal candidate should be well-versed in project management methodologies, technological fields, and have a strong technical background.

Key Responsibilities:

  • Project Planning & Execution:

    • Lead the planning and implementation of technical projects, ensuring they are completed according to outlined objectives.
    • Develop a detailed project plan to track progress and ensure projects are delivered on time, within scope, and within budget.
    • Coordinate internal resources and third parties/vendors for flawless project execution.

    Scope, Risk & Quality Management:

    • Manage changes to project scope, schedule, and costs using appropriate verification techniques.
    • Perform risk management to minimize project risks.
    • Oversee quality assurance processes to ensure project objectives are met.

    Performance Tracking & Reporting:

    • Measure project performance using appropriate systems, tools, and techniques.
    • Report on project progress and escalate issues to management as needed.
    • Create and maintain comprehensive project documentation.

    Technical Guidance & Feasibility:

    • Ensure technical feasibility and resource availability for project execution.
    • Provide technical guidance and support to the project team.

    Stakeholder Engagement & Post-Project Evaluation:

    • Conduct stakeholder management activities, ensuring clear communication throughout the project lifecycle.
    • Conduct post-project evaluation and identify successful and unsuccessful project elements.

Qualifications:

  • Bachelor's degree in Computing Science, Information Technology, or a related field (not essential).

Preferred Skills & Experience:

  • Minimum of 5 years of experience in project management in the information technology sector.
  • Proven working experience as a Technical Project Manager.
  • Solid technical background, with understanding or hands-on experience in software development and web technologies.
  • Excellent client-facing and internal communication skills.
  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills.
  • Solid organisational skills including attention to detail and multi-tasking skills.
  • Strong working knowledge of Microsoft Office and Jira.
  • Project Management Professional (PMP) / PRINCE II certification.
  • Specific technical skills required: Experience with Contact Centres and AWS (Amazon Web Services).
  • Experience with Microsoft Modern Work (Desirable but not essential).

Post title: The Hidden Costs of Poor User Adoption
Post SEO title: The Hidden Costs of Poor User Adoption
Meta description: Discover the hidden costs of poor user adoption and learn strategies for effective change management to ensure lasting transformation and boost productivity in your organisation.
Post body:
Welcome to our new series: Momentum: The change Journey! 

Change isn‚Äôt just about new technology or processes - it‚Äôs about people. Momentum: The Change Journey is a series dedicated to unlocking the power of effective change management, helping organisations move from resistance to readiness, and ensuring that transformation sticks. Through expert insights, practical strategies, and real-world stories, we‚Äôll explore how to build adoption momentum and create lasting impact.

Is it just me or has adoption become a project buzz word? Yes, the word ‚Äòadopt‚Äô can also mean to ‚Äòuse‚Äô something ‚Äì but I guarantee that handsome bottom line of your benefits spreadsheet assumes that people aren‚Äôt just ‚Äòdoing‚Äô the new thing ‚Äì they‚Äôre doing it well. Ready to save your company from low ROI, disengaged teams and one giant headache? Welcome, to the hidden costs of poor adoption.

Eliza Taylor | Change Director

The 100% Illusion

Picture this: your company rolls out shiny new technology and, voila, everyone‚Äôs using it! That‚Äôs 100% adoption, right? Not so fast. If you don‚Äôt put in the work to change existing processes and behaviours, you‚Äôre not going to see those promised boosts in productivity, security, or customer satisfaction. It‚Äôs like buying an airplane and then using it to drive around on the ground.

There‚Äôs a difference between use and adoption, and every business case I‚Äôve seen has a built-in assumption that there are going to be productivity, efficiency or optimisation gains because of the shiny new tool. But does that business case also feature sufficient resources to ensure a high rate of adoption? Hmmm.

Let‚Äôs dive into some juicy real-world examples to see what we mean:

Undermining Machine Learning

You introduce a new forecasting system to nail agent scheduling and capacity planning in a contact centre, so no customer is left waiting too long at peak times. Its predictive analysis is based on historic data and machine learning, so the more you use it, the better it gets. Awesome right? Except that some teams have reached change overload and decide to keep managing vacation and overtime through good old spreadsheets and forms. The result? There‚Äôs still some benefit, but 50+ people are still doing something manually because it‚Äôs what they‚Äôre used to.

Data Black Holes

You‚Äôve upgraded to a scalable, cloud-based solution with cutting-edge customer sentiment analysis. Every interaction automatically generates data about how the customer felt throughout the conversation, key triggers, talk vs listening time and more. The potential! This could be used for training, incentives, performance reviews and upselling opportunities. Except that nothing happens with your new report. The headline NPS is shared with the business once a month and voila ‚Äì what a missed opportunity.

Modern Working the Old Way

You expand the features of your online collaboration tools ‚Äì enabling version history, co-authoring and key content labels for secure external sharing. Gone are the version errors of the past, gone are the hours wasted working on duplicates, gone are the enormous data storage costs‚Ä¶or are they? Your employees continue to email physical copies instead of sharing links and save new files for every version. Rocket ship to the future, crashed.

The Butterfly Effect

The impact of poor user adoption isn‚Äôt just a one-off issue. It spreads like wildfire, eroding benefits and return on investment, and forcing extra investment to fix new issues caused by not using things as intended.

Now, picture the impact on your teams ‚Äì they've had a rocky change experience and are left clueless about their new tools. Their daily grind just got a whole lot tougher ‚Äì and they‚Äôre being criticised for not delivering the improved results that were expected. Are they going to be at their best? Probably not.

At best, you‚Äôre looking at significant drops in productivity, morale, and goodwill both during and after the project. At worst, your top talent might jump ship for greener pastures ‚Äì and their replacements will simply inherit the same inefficient habits.

Change is hard work and impacts productivity even before launch ‚Äì those months of prep, announcements, workshops and training add up, all on top of regular duties. The secret to keeping everyone engaged and productive through all stages? Investing in solid change management ‚Äì otherwise, you're watering down the business benefits before the change even takes off.

Strategies for Successful User Adoption

So, how do we turn this ship around? Here are some strategies to get everyone on board for a smoother transition and better realisation of those juicy benefits:

  • Clear Communication: We need to make sure everyone knows what‚Äôs going on, why we‚Äôre doing it, and what‚Äôs in it for them. Be genuine and authentic when addressing their doubts and paint a clear picture of the change journey.
  • Tailored Training: Forget one-size-fits-all. Create customised training that goes beyond the technical stuff. Don‚Äôt just leave it to the technical team to talk about features, make sure the business teams are ready to revamp their processes and include this in the training ‚Äì this way, they‚Äôll be ready to make the most out of the new tools.
  • Continuous Support: Keep the support flowing! From help desks to user guides and regular check-ins, be there every step of the way to iron out any issues and make sure that support teams are aligned with process changes and best practice advice as well.
  • Incentivise Adoption: Let‚Äôs celebrate the early adopters! Recognise and reward those who are smashing it with the new processes. This will boost morale and inspire others to join the party.

Wrapping It Up

So, did you spot these hidden costs? I bet you a coffee you won‚Äôt find them in any risk or benefits spreadsheets!

I think these pitfalls can be seriously underestimated by business leaders focussed on the potential benefits ‚Äì never realising that their big picture could be seriously undermined before they even start.

The good news is that by recognising these challenges and using smart strategies to boost real adoption, companies can truly unlock the full potential of their investments. And better adoption means happier, more productive people (I mean, who wants their work to be harder or less efficient!?). Remember, true transformation is more than just skin-deep changes - it calls for a committed effort to alter behaviours and processes for lasting impact.

If you're interested in taking advantage of our free 30-minute strategy session, or you want to take me up on the coffee offer, book your session below, or you can use good old-fashioned email to drop me a note: eliza.taylor@cloudinteract.io 

{{cta('205068514499','justifycenter')}}

Post title: Episode 28 - User Adoption
Post SEO title: Episode 28 - User Adoption
Meta description: Dive into why bringing people along for the journey is just as important as getting the technical setup right when rolling out Amazon Connect.
Post body:
Mastering User Adoption in Amazon Connect

User adoption - it‚Äôs the often-overlooked factor that determines whether a new technology implementation is a success or a struggle. In the latest ACP Podcast, hosts Tom Morgan and Alex Baker dive into why bringing people along for the journey is just as important as getting the technical setup right when rolling out Amazon Connect. From the latest product updates to the role of AI in improving agent performance, here‚Äôs what you need to know.

{{cta('213075106005','justifycenter')}}

User Adoption: The Key to Success

One of the biggest pitfalls in contact centre technology rollouts is assuming that a well-executed technical deployment automatically leads to a successful project. In reality, the real challenge often lies in user adoption. If agents, supervisors, and business users aren‚Äôt engaged and supported, even the best technology can go underutilised.

Start With ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù

For any organisation moving to Amazon Connect, it‚Äôs crucial to understand and articulate the why behind the transition. Whether upgrading from a legacy contact centre or implementing a formal contact centre for the first time, decision-makers need to clearly communicate the benefits, such as:

  • Improved agent workflows
  • Greater flexibility and scalability
  • Enhanced reporting and analytics

Address Resistance to Change

Change is hard - especially when it impacts people‚Äôs daily routines. Agents accustomed to older systems may resist a new interface or workflow unless they understand the advantages. Leaders and technical teams must be prepared to:

  • Educate early ‚Äì Communicate what‚Äôs changing and why, well before the rollout.
  • Listen to concerns ‚Äì Acknowledge fears about change and address them with tangible solutions.
  • Demonstrate quick wins ‚Äì Show how the new system simplifies their work, not just adds complexity.

The Role of Training

Training is an essential component of user adoption, but it must be tailored to different user groups:

  • Agents ‚Äì Focus on ease of use and efficiency in their daily tasks.
  • Supervisors & Managers ‚Äì Ensure they can access and analyse performance data effectively.
  • Quality & Compliance Teams ‚Äì Provide specialised training on evaluations, reporting, and adherence.

For smaller teams, informal training may be sufficient, but in large enterprises, structured onboarding is necessary to maintain consistency.

AI & Automation: Enabling, Not Replacing Agents

The rise of AI in contact centres has led to concerns about job displacement, but the real opportunity lies in augmenting human agents, not replacing them. AI-driven tools like Amazon Q can support agents by:

  • Providing real-time assistance and knowledge retrieval.
  • Automating repetitive queries (e.g., ‚ÄúWhere is my order?‚Äù inquiries).
  • Enhancing agent workflows to focus on high-value interactions.

By removing routine, low-value tasks, AI allows agents to focus on complex and emotionally sensitive customer interactions where human empathy is irreplaceable.

Continuous Adoption & Optimisation

User adoption isn‚Äôt a one-time event - it‚Äôs an ongoing process. Organisations should:

  • Regularly review Amazon Connect updates to take advantage of new features.
  • Refine training programmes based on evolving business needs and new hires.
  • Leverage managed services to stay up to date with best practices and innovations.

The success of any Amazon Connect implementation depends on more than just getting the technology right. Engaging agents, supervisors, and stakeholders throughout the process ensures that new capabilities are effectively utilised, enhancing customer experience and operational efficiency.

By prioritising user adoption from day one - and sustaining it through training, AI integration, and ongoing optimisation - organisations can maximise the value of Amazon Connect and future-proof their contact centers.

Post body:
From Complexity to Clarity ‚Äì How Apollo is Transforming Contact Centres

The modern contact centre is a complex, ever-evolving environment. Businesses are dealing with an explosion of customer interactions across multiple channels, leading to data overload, operational inefficiencies, and rising customer expectations. The recent webinar, From Complexity to Clarity: Uncovering Hidden Insights with Apollo, explored how businesses can cut through the noise and leverage AI-driven data intelligence to drive meaningful improvements.

If you missed it, you can watch the full webinar recording here:

 

Key Highlights from the Webinar

Eliza Taylor, Change Director at CloudInteract, and Tom Morgan, Engineering Lead, opened the discussion by highlighting the rapid growth in contact centres. While growth is positive, it often results in fragmented systems, inconsistent data silos, and manual processes that slow down decision-making.

Agents juggle multiple tools, customers expect seamless interactions, and IT teams are left struggling with data that doesn‚Äôt translate into actionable insights. As Tom put it, ‚ÄúContact centres are leaking data everywhere, but none of it actually tells you what‚Äôs working and what‚Äôs not.‚Äù

Apollo: Turning Data into Real Intelligence

Apollo was built to solve these challenges. Instead of just producing more dashboards, it uses AI to:
‚úî Break down data silos and categorise interactions automatically
‚úî Identify inefficiencies in customer journeys and agent workflows
‚úî Provide actionable recommendations to improve service delivery
‚úî Help businesses build a clear, data-backed case for transformation

The Power of AI-Driven Insights

The webinar featured a live demo showcasing Apollo‚Äôs ability to analyse customer interactions, uncover hidden trends, and suggest automation opportunities. In one example, Apollo detected that 96% of calls about address changes were simple and automatable, highlighting a clear case for process improvement.

Your Questions Answered

Question: How does Apollo handle multi-channel support?

It integrates seamlessly with phone, chat, and email.

Question: Can Apollo integrate with existing CRMs and third-party tools?

Yes, it's designed to work within your tech ecosystem.

Question: What‚Äôs the ROI of deploying Apollo?

It depends on your business goals, but examples include reducing verification time, cutting down queue bottlenecks, and optimising scheduling.

Watch the Webinar Recording

Want to see Apollo in action and hear from industry experts? Watch the webinar recording here.

Post title: Episode 27 - Automation
Post SEO title: Episode 27 - Automation
Meta description: Automation isn‚Äôt just about AI. It‚Äôs about leveraging technology to streamline processes, improve efficiency, and ultimately enhance the customer experience.
Post body:
Unlocking the Power of Automation in the Contact Centre

Automation is a hot topic in the contact centre space right now, especially as AI continues to shape the landscape of customer service. But as Tom Morgan and Alex Baker explore in the latest episode of the ACP podcast, automation isn‚Äôt just about AI. It‚Äôs about leveraging technology to streamline processes, improve efficiency, and ultimately enhance the customer experience.

{{cta('213075104988','justifycenter')}}

 

What Do We Mean by Automation?

Automation in the contact centre is all about using technology to handle tasks that traditionally required human intervention. This could mean improving efficiencies, reducing costs, or even enabling new capabilities that weren‚Äôt previously possible. More importantly, automation should go beyond cost-cutting to actually enhance the customer and agent experience.

The True Value of Automation

While automation is often associated with improving productivity, it‚Äôs not just about doing more with less. Tom and Alex emphasize that automation should be focused on improving customer interactions, empowering agents, and driving business efficiencies. Some key benefits include:

  • Enhanced customer experience: Automation can help route calls more effectively, provide instant responses, and reduce wait times.
  • Empowered agents: By automating repetitive tasks, agents can focus on more complex and meaningful customer interactions.
  • Reduced operational costs: Streamlining workflows and self-service options can lower the burden on human agents and optimise resources.
  • Scalability: Businesses can handle higher volumes of interactions without needing to exponentially grow their workforce.

Where Automation Shows Up in the Contact Centre

There are multiple areas where automation is already making an impact in Amazon Connect and the wider contact centre ecosystem:

1. Routing and IVR Enhancements

One of the earliest forms of automation in contact centres was the IVR (Interactive Voice Response) system, which replaced manual switchboards. Today, automation is evolving beyond simple ‚ÄúPress 1 for Sales‚Äù menus to AI-driven chatbots and voice assistants that can understand and route queries more effectively.

2. Self-Service Capabilities

Automation enables customers to resolve their issues without speaking to an agent. Whether it‚Äôs checking an order status, resetting a password, or requesting a refund, self-service systems powered by AI and natural language processing can drastically improve efficiency.

3. Agent Assistance & Workflow Automation

  • Step-by-Step Guidance: Providing agents with real-time guided workflows based on customer interactions.
  • Knowledge Base Integration: Using AI to surface relevant information to agents during live calls.
  • Post-Call Follow-Ups: Automatically sending customers summaries of their interactions via SMS or email.

4. Outbound Campaigns & Proactive Engagement

Amazon Connect‚Äôs outbound dialer allows businesses to automate proactive customer engagement across multiple channels. This means businesses can reach out to customers via SMS, email, or phone calls to send reminders, promotions, or service updates efficiently.

5. Quality Monitoring & AI-Powered Evaluations

Traditional quality monitoring often involves manually reviewing a small sample of calls per agent. With automation, businesses can analyze every call, ensuring compliance, assessing agent performance, and identifying areas for improvement. Amazon Connect‚Äôs Contact Lens can even use AI to evaluate customer interactions in real time.

6. Automated Testing for Reliability

One often-overlooked area of automation is testing. Instead of manually checking if a contact center system is working, businesses can use automated testing tools to simulate customer interactions and ensure everything is functioning correctly at all times.

Take Action: Conduct an Automation Audit

Tom and Alex suggest that businesses conduct an ‚Äúautomation audit‚Äù to assess where they currently stand and where they could implement automation. Here‚Äôs how:

  1. List all current automated processes ‚Äì Identify what‚Äôs already in place and working.
  2. Identify opportunities for further automation ‚Äì Look for areas where automation could improve efficiency or enhance CX.
  3. Assess AI-readiness ‚Äì Understand where AI could be incorporated and how it aligns with your data and business processes.

Automation is no longer a futuristic concept - it‚Äôs here, and it‚Äôs evolving rapidly. Whether it‚Äôs optimising call routing, empowering agents, enhancing self-service, or automating quality monitoring, businesses that embrace automation will be better equipped to provide exceptional customer experiences.

{{cta('213075104988','justifycenter')}}

Post title: What's New in Amazon Connect - February 2025
Post SEO title: What's New in Amazon Connect - February 2025
Meta description: Keeping up with Amazon Connect‚Äôs continuous innovation is key to ensuring your contact centre operates at its best. If you missed our latest session, don‚Äôt worry - we‚Äôve compiled the highlights for you.
Post body:
Amazon Connect: What's New - February 2025

Enhancing Contact Centre Efficiency with the Latest Updates

Keeping up with Amazon Connect‚Äôs continuous innovation is key to ensuring your contact centre operates at its best. If you missed our latest session, don‚Äôt worry - we‚Äôve compiled the highlights for you. Whether you‚Äôre looking for faster call handling, smarter agent workflows, or enhanced analytics, this update brings several key improvements that can help streamline operations and improve customer experience.


Hot off the press from our resident Contact Centre Consultant and AWS Solution Architect, Alex Baker. Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new this month:

 

{{cta('212022526157')}}

Key Enhancements in This Release

Persistent Agent Connections (Public Preview)

Connecting customers to agents faster is crucial, especially for outbound campaigns. Amazon Connect now offers persistent agent connections, reducing the time needed to establish a call by keeping an open channel between the agent‚Äôs softphone and Amazon Connect. This feature ensures compliance with regulations like the US Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) by maintaining quick connection times.

Why this matters:

  • Reduces call connection delays
  • Enhances agent efficiency for outbound dialling
  • Improves compliance with telemarketing laws

Screen Recording for AWS GovCloud (US-West)

Government and public sector organisations can now use screen recording in AWS GovCloud (US-West). This feature enhances compliance and security for government entities using Amazon Connect.

Improved Audio Optimisation for Citrix and Amazon WorkSpaces

Agents using Citrix or Amazon WorkSpaces Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) can now redirect audio to their local devices, improving voice quality and reducing latency. This enhancement ensures that calls handled on virtual desktops provide a better experience for both customers and agents.

How it works:

  • Requires a simple query parameter in the Agent Workspace URL
  • Works for non-SSO and SSO users with relay state updates

Automatic Agent Performance Evaluation Emails

Agent performance tracking just got more efficient. Supervisors can now set up automated emails to notify agents when their calls are evaluated. This allows them to quickly review feedback, improve performance, and stay aligned with quality standards.

Key benefits:

  • Real-time feedback for agents
  • Custom rules to trigger notifications based on evaluation scores
  • Streamlined coaching and performance tracking

Conditionally Required Fields in Amazon Connect Cases

Data accuracy is critical in customer support. This new feature allows admins to create conditionally required fields in Amazon Connect Cases, ensuring that agents capture the right information at the right time.

Example use cases:

  • A ‚ÄúClose Reason‚Äù field becomes mandatory when a case is closed
  • A ‚ÄúProduct Serial Number‚Äù is required when the issue type is hardware-related
  • A ‚ÄúDisposition Code‚Äù is needed for system-generated cases

Customisable Agent Schedule Adherence Tracking

Amazon Connect now lets you map agent statuses more flexibly to schedule activities. This means you can define which states are considered "adherent," improving workforce tracking.

Example:
If an agent is scheduled for "Work," they can now be in either "Available" or "Back-office Work" and still be considered adherent.

Multi-Proficiency Routing Enhancement

Routing just got more powerful. You can now target up to four agent proficiency combinations in a single routing step. This means contacts have a better chance of being matched with a skilled agent, improving resolution rates.

New Agent Performance Evaluation Dashboard

A new Agent Performance Dashboard provides unified insights into:

  • Evaluation scores
  • Productivity metrics (contacts handled, average handle time, etc.)
  • Trends and performance comparisons over time

This dashboard helps supervisors easily identify agent strengths and areas for improvement at a glance.

Generative AI Use Cases Workshop

Amazon Connect‚Äôs Generative AI capabilities continue to expand, and now there‚Äôs a dedicated workshop covering:

  • Self-service experiences powered by Generative AI
  • Agent evaluations and conversational analytics
  • AI-powered agent assistance

This self-paced AWS workshop is available online and is highly recommended for teams exploring the full potential of Generative AI in customer interactions.

Final Thoughts

This release brings powerful enhancements to Amazon Connect, from faster call handling to AI-driven insights and agent performance tracking. These updates provide businesses with more control, efficiency, and better customer experiences.

Excited to learn more? Download our What‚Äôs New in Amazon Connect overview, or contact our team to talk so more.

Post title: Transform Resistance into Readiness: Strategies for Change Leaders
Post SEO title: Transform Resistance into Readiness: Strategies for Change Leaders
Meta description: Your company, your people and your change are unique. There isn‚Äôt a cookie-cutter fix all. You need to take the time to understand your context to authentically address resistance.
Post body:
Welcome to our series: Momentum: The Change Journey! 

Eliza Taylor | Change Director

Change isn‚Äôt just about new technology or processes - it‚Äôs about people. Momentum: The Change Journey is a series dedicated to unlocking the power of effective change management, helping organisations move from resistance to readiness, and ensuring that transformation sticks. Through expert insights, practical strategies, and real-world stories, we‚Äôll explore how to build adoption momentum and create lasting impact.

Change is an essential part of growth for any organisation, but let‚Äôs face it - change often meets resistance. Whether you‚Äôre introducing new strategies, technologies, or processes, the key is to transform that resistance into readiness.

Explain the Why

It may sound odd, but sometimes leaders skip the 'why' and dive straight into the 'what'. But that 'why' is the golden key to your success (or without it, the start of a bumpy ride).

Words like ‚Äúimprovement‚Äù, ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù, or ‚Äúoptimisation‚Äù just won't cut it. There's always a bigger picture. Are you moving resources into new strategic areas, aiming for a fresh market or product, trying to keep pace with competitors, shaking off legacy tech no longer fit-for-purpose, or charting a bold, new direction for the company? Share that story with your people!

And here‚Äôs the kicker: Your business is probably juggling multiple changes at once. Aligning all these initiatives with your high-level goals makes everything feel like part of a grand plan, rather than a chaotic jigsaw puzzle.

Listen Up

Big announcements from key leaders are a great start, but let‚Äôs be real ‚Äì they're just the tip of the iceberg. Think about how many unread emails are sitting in your inbox right now. You can't just drop a bombshell and walk away.

You need a steady stream of communication throughout your project. This isn‚Äôt just to keep everyone in the loop; it‚Äôs to keep the excitement alive, gauge reactions, and build momentum as you rack up those wins.

Take a broad approach when it comes to engagement and communication. Don‚Äôt just engage stakeholders; dive into employee forums, arrange Q&A sessions (like roadshows or lunch n‚Äô learns), and recruit champions who can spread the word in every corner of your business.

Opening up two-way communication channels takes effort, but it‚Äôs worth it. It‚Äôs not just about making sure your workforce feels heard; sometimes, you‚Äôll get critical insights that stop the project derailing. Trust me, those red flags have saved the day more than once!

Idealism Meets Realism

‚ÄúThis is our most important internal initiative ‚Äì budget is no issue, just get it done well.‚Äù Said almost no company, ever.

Business is business, and the reality often involves tight resources and teams stretched thin. You still need to get everyone on board with the change, making sure they‚Äôre actively involved while juggling their daily tasks, but you don‚Äôt have endless time or resources to make this happen.

Balancing ideal solutions with practical constraints is key. In a perfect world, you‚Äôd have custom workshops, face-to-face engagement, plenty of incentives, and bespoke training for every part of the business that everyone attends. But let's face it, most projects can‚Äôt hit all those marks.

So, use your resources wisely. Focus on what truly makes a difference. If time and people are in short supply, think about a train-the-trainer approach to spread the knowledge. Prioritise workshops for the folks who will feel the impact the most. Even if you can't create the perfect experience, aim to make a real difference where it counts.

Can You be Trusted?

Let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äì everyone has at least one example of a poor change experience, where cryptic messaging and emergency action delivered lots of pain with very little benefit.

Trust reduces resistance. You want employees to trust that their leaders care about the impact and are being as transparent and supportive as they can, even when they are facing the toughest decisions. This isn‚Äôt about ‚Äòspinning‚Äô the story ‚Äì trust significantly affects your ability to keep talent and do business, as well as how agile you can be in change.

Make sure you deliver, if you say that employees will be consulted, trained and supported ‚Äì believe me, employees will definitely notice if they aren't.

Maintaining Momentum

Recognise that change takes effort. It‚Äôs not always easy, but it's worth it. Acknowledge those who jump in with both feet. Celebrate small wins. As change fatigue grows, you can rejuvenate your programme by highlighting teams that are making progress, using them as positive examples of future benefits.

When things get bumpy (and they will), tackle problems constructively and with understanding. Nobody wants a blame game ‚Äì we all want solutions and a chance to learn from mistakes without fear of being singled out.  Fear will grow resistance.

Making change happen isn‚Äôt just about implementing new processes or systems ‚Äì it‚Äôs about creating an environment where people feel proud, motivated, and ready to tackle the future. Keep the energy high, communication flowing, and celebrate those wins. Your enthusiasm will be contagious, and soon you‚Äôll have a team that‚Äôs not just ready for change but ready for it.

Conclusion

Turning resistance into readiness isn‚Äôt a walk in the park, but it‚Äôs definitely doable with the right approach. Picture this: a clear vision, open and honest communication, and plenty of feedback flying back and forth. Show your team you appreciate their hard work, build trust by standing by your promises, and get everyone from top to bottom involved.

Above all, your company, your people and your change are unique. There isn‚Äôt a cookie-cutter fix all. You need to take the time, every time, to understand your context to authentically address resistance.

Interested in hearing more? Join Eliza and Tom Morgan, Solutions Architect in our next webinar - 26th February 2025. Find out more and register...
